ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I think this class could have been more concrete in its discussions.

I think this course needs to be re-thought for the next time it is offered. Its a shame because the subject-matter itself is so interesting, but not a lot is taught directly from the professor to the student. Student presentations at the beginning and end of the semester took up so much time, that the actual class itself in between then felt lack-luster. I suggest for the professor to restructure the class to be more lecture based rather than discussion.

Strengths: she provided theoretical background needed to understand whats at stake surrounding the topic, the students in the class were also really engaged, genuine and insightful. The final project also felt really rewarding and she gave us full latitude to do explore whatever we wanted to.
Weaknesses: the readings were sometimes long and convoluted, some of the activities didnt always resonate and when that happened they felt a bit burdensome but it was all manageable and the rubric and feedback didnt always make sense.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Not really. I personally came into the class wanting to be able to gain a better picture of the problem but I'm leaving the class basically the same way I entered...6/12 of the weeks were presentations, 1 week was a tour of a temporary exhibit, 1 we rewatched a movie that was assigned in our readings, another 1 was a mock trial to return objects that everyone knows we have to return anyway. We didn't engage with the readings and we didn't going into the African art gallery. Whatever discussion we did have felt like a classic, fake humanities/SJW class with everyone saying the words "colonialism" without any real discussion. I wanted to be able to expand my knowledge so that I can defend my opinions and take my discussion to the next level. That's not really what happened.

Yes! Professor Fromont is very kind and willing to share her expertise in the art history field! Not often do you get a class dedicated to discussing art issues specifically relating to sub-Saharan Africa
Yes, I would - few classes cover this topic and it was well done all thing considered.

extras.title: ANTH 403 01/ARCG 406 01/HSAR 407 01 - In, Out, and Back: African Art
